title: Active Tills - Find the last time a till was traded on
text: When asked to find how many tills are in use at a site: ;WITH cte AS ( SELECT *, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY txhtillno ORDER BY txhcompleted DESC) AS rn FROM TXNHeader ) SELECT tilTillNo [Till No.], tilLocation [Till Location], txhCompleted [Last Transaction] FROM cte JOIN Tills on tilTillNo=txhTillNo WHERE rn = 1 AND tilInactive=0 AND tilTillType=0 ORDER BY tilTillNo asc
description:
When asked to find how many tills are in use at a site:


;WITH cte AS 


( 


SELECT *, 


ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY txhtillno ORDER BY txhcompleted DESC) AS rn 


FROM  TXNHeader


) 


SELECT tilTillNo [Till No.], tilLocation [Till Location], txhCompleted [Last Transaction]


FROM cte 


JOIN Tills on tilTillNo=txhTillNo


WHERE rn = 1 AND tilInactive=0 AND tilTillType=0


ORDER BY tilTillNo asc

title: Booking price calculation
text: If troubleshooting and a booking doesn't add up correctly or is not giving an expected result. Use the below SQL to check what the system is returning: Select txnTillNo, sum(isnull(txnLineSellValue,0)) As AmountPaid From TXNDetail Where txnBranch = 1 and txnOrderNo = 1989 AND txnStatus <> 'V' AND txnType NOT IN ('P','O','D','L','Z','Y','C','G','U','W') Group by txnStatus, txnTillNo Change the booking number in bold as required.
description:
If troubleshooting and a booking doesn't add up correctly or is not giving an expected result. Use the below SQL to check what the system is returning:


Select txnTillNo,  sum(isnull(txnLineSellValue,0)) As AmountPaid  From TXNDetail Where txnBranch = 1 and txnOrderNo = 1989 AND txnStatus <> 'V' AND txnType NOT IN ('P','O','D','L','Z','Y','C','G','U','W')  Group by txnStatus, txnTillNo


Change the booking number in bold as required.

title: PExcelReps.exe For Cloud-Hosted Customers
text: If you are setting up or a customer has an issue with running a report that requires PExcelReps.exe for a cloud-hosted customer, there is a new version they need, that has a PExcelReps.exe.config accompanying this, where the customers SQL user login and password that needs to be specified. Both these files are attached. Make sure you insert the SQL username in between the xxxxx field under line, and SQL password in the xxxxx below the . You do not need to do the same for any of the other fields.
description:
If you are setting up or a customer has an issue with running a report that requires PExcelReps.exe for a cloud-hosted customer, there is a new version they need, that has a PExcelReps.exe.config accompanying this, where the customers SQL user login and password that needs to be specified.


Both these files are attached. Make sure you insert the SQL username in between the <value>xxxxx</value> field under <setting name="User" serializeAs="String"> line, and SQL password in the <value>xxxxx</value> below the <setting name="PW" serializeAs="String">.


You do not need to do the same for any of the other fields.

title: SessionBkgs Records Not Clearing After Being Set To Unpaid Reservations
text: If you find that there are sessions that are not fully booked in Sessions/Tours, but they do not show online, and the customer is on quite an old version of MStore (3.15.8r or lower), this could be because the SessionBkgs records linked to the unpaid reservation bookings are not being cleared. There was something implemented in a later version. Therefore, an upgrade would fix this for future unpaid reservations. However, in order to clear the current records that are holding onto this session availability, you will need to do the below. Backup the BKGHeader and SessionBkgs tables. Set unpaid reservations back to BkhStatus of R. Set these bookings back to Z and deleting the linked records from within SessionBkgs and SessionsSeats. SQL for each of these steps can be found below: --1 DECLARE @SQL1 NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKBKGHeader'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM BKGHeader' EXEC (@SQL1); DECLARE @SQL2 NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKSessionBkgs'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM SessionBkgs' EXEC (@SQL2) --2 BEGIN TRANSACTION UPDATE BKGHeader SET bkhStatus='R' WHERE bkhArrivalTime > '1 JAN 2024' AND bkhStatus='Z' AND ISNULL(bkhIsInternet,0)=1 AND bkhBranch=1 --COMMIT --3 declare @tBkh table (bkRef int) insert @tBkh select bkhRef from Bkgheader where bkhBranch=1 and bkhStatus='R' and ISNULL(bkhIsInternet,0)=1 and datediff(minute,bkhBookedOn,getdate()) >= 60 UPDATE dbo.Bkgheader SET bkhStatus='Z', bkhNotes='Unpaid reservation' WHERE bkhBranch=1 and bkhRef in (select bkRef from @tBkh) DELETE SessionBkgs Where sesBranch = 1 and sesbkhRef in (select bkRef from @tBkh) DELETE SessionSeats Where sstBranch = 1 and sstSesBkhRef in (select bkRef from @tBkh)
description:
If you find that there are sessions that are not fully booked in Sessions/Tours, but they do not show online, and the customer is on quite an old version of MStore (3.15.8r or lower), this could be because the SessionBkgs records linked to the unpaid reservation bookings are not being cleared.


There was something implemented in a later version. Therefore, an upgrade would fix this for future unpaid reservations. However, in order to clear the current records that are holding onto this session availability, you will need to do the below.


  1. Backup the BKGHeader and SessionBkgs tables.

  2. Set unpaid reservations back to BkhStatus of R.

  3. Set these bookings back to Z and deleting the linked records from within SessionBkgs and SessionsSeats.


SQL for each of these steps can be found below:

--1
DECLARE @SQL1 NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKBKGHeader'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM BKGHeader'
EXEC (@SQL1);
DECLARE @SQL2 NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKSessionBkgs'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM SessionBkgs'
EXEC (@SQL2)

--2
BEGIN TRANSACTION 
UPDATE BKGHeader
SET bkhStatus='R'
WHERE bkhArrivalTime > '1 JAN 2024' AND bkhStatus='Z' AND ISNULL(bkhIsInternet,0)=1 
AND bkhBranch=1
--COMMIT 

--3
declare @tBkh table (bkRef int)
insert @tBkh select bkhRef from Bkgheader where bkhBranch=1 and bkhStatus='R' and ISNULL(bkhIsInternet,0)=1  and datediff(minute,bkhBookedOn,getdate()) >= 60

UPDATE dbo.Bkgheader 
SET bkhStatus='Z', bkhNotes='Unpaid reservation' 
  WHERE bkhBranch=1 and bkhRef in (select bkRef from  @tBkh)

DELETE SessionBkgs Where sesBranch = 1 and sesbkhRef in (select bkRef from  @tBkh)

DELETE SessionSeats  Where sstBranch  = 1 and sstSesBkhRef  in (select bkRef from  @tBkh)

title: SQL For Analysing InternetTransactionAudit Table When Customers Querying Online Payments
text: If customers are questioning online payments, whether payments have gone through, but at a delay, or payments have gone through, but our customer did not receive the money, you can use the below SQL to help show what happened. SELECT itaWebBkgID [Web Booking ID], cusForeNames +' '+ cusSurname [Name], itaDateStamp [Booking Date], CASE WHEN itaPaidStatus = 1 THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END [Paid?], itaPaidDate [Paid Date], itaBkhref [Booking Ref.], pluShortDesc FROM InternetTransactionAudit LEFT JOIN Customer ON itaAccRecNo=cusAccRecNo AND itaCusSeq=cusSeq LEFT JOIN BKGHeader ON itaBkhref=bkhRef LEFT JOIN BKGDetail ON itaBkhref=bkdRef AND itaBkdSeq=bkdSeq LEFT JOIN BarCodes ON bkdBCDId=bcdId LEFT JOIN PriceLookups ON bcdPLURecNo=pluRecNo WHERE itaDateStamp BETWEEN '' AND '' ORDER BY itaDateStamp DESC
description:
If customers are questioning online payments, whether payments have gone through, but at a delay, or payments have gone through, but our customer did not receive the money, you can use the below SQL to help show what happened.


SELECT itaWebBkgID [Web Booking ID], cusForeNames +' '+ cusSurname [Name], itaDateStamp [Booking Date],
CASE WHEN itaPaidStatus = 1  THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END [Paid?], itaPaidDate [Paid Date], itaBkhref [Booking Ref.], pluShortDesc FROM InternetTransactionAudit
LEFT JOIN Customer ON itaAccRecNo=cusAccRecNo AND itaCusSeq=cusSeq
LEFT JOIN BKGHeader ON itaBkhref=bkhRef
LEFT JOIN BKGDetail ON itaBkhref=bkdRef AND itaBkdSeq=bkdSeq
LEFT JOIN BarCodes ON bkdBCDId=bcdId
LEFT JOIN PriceLookups ON bcdPLURecNo=pluRecNo
WHERE itaDateStamp BETWEEN '' AND '' 
 ORDER BY itaDateStamp DESC

title: Run Fix Stock Take Within SQL
text: If you are running the Fix Stock Take process and it throws a timeout message because calculating the stock movements for some items take longer than what the system has been set at 30 seconds, you can run this process in SQL with this looping SQL statement: DECLARE @i INT = 0 DECLARE @m INT SELECT @m = MAX(stkRecNo) FROM Stock WHILE @i < @m BEGIN SET @i = @i + 1 EXEC MC_FixStockTake 1, @i, 0 Print @i END
description:
If you are running the Fix Stock Take process and it throws a timeout message because calculating the stock movements for some items take longer than what the system has been set at 30 seconds, you can run this process in SQL with this looping SQL statement: 

DECLARE @i INT = 0
DECLARE @m INT
SELECT @m = MAX(stkRecNo) FROM Stock

WHILE @i < @m
BEGIN
  SET @i = @i + 1
  EXEC MC_FixStockTake 1, @i, 0
  Print @i
END

title: Bookings With Allocation Discrepancies Data Extract
text: This data extract will show all the bookings where its session allocation for each journey leg do not match one another. SQL is below, and screen shot instructions is below that. SELECT a.sesbkhRef [Booking Ref.], a.sesBkdSeq [Booking Resource Sequence], pluShortDesc [PLU Description], b.sesNum [Allocation Amount], b.sesJourneyLeg [Journey Leg], b.sesAddedOn [Added Onto Session] FROM ( SELECT sesbkhRef, sesBkdSeq FROM SessionBkgs GROUP BY sesbkhRef, sesBkdSeq HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT sesNum) > 1 ) a JOIN SessionBkgs b ON a.sesbkhRef=b.sesbkhRef AND a.sesBkdSeq=b.sesBkdSeq JOIN BKGDetail ON a.sesbkhRef=bkdRef AND a.sesBkdSeq=bkdSeq JOIN BarCodes ON bkdBCDId=bcdId JOIN PriceLookups ON bcdPLURecNo=pluRecNo WHERE sesAddedOn > '1 JAN 2024' ORDER BY a.sesbkhRef DESC, a.sesBkdSeq
description:
This data extract will show all the bookings where its session allocation for each journey leg do not match one another. SQL is below, and screen shot instructions is below that.


SELECT a.sesbkhRef [Booking Ref.], a.sesBkdSeq [Booking Resource Sequence], pluShortDesc [PLU Description], b.sesNum [Allocation Amount], b.sesJourneyLeg [Journey Leg], b.sesAddedOn [Added Onto Session] FROM (
  SELECT sesbkhRef, sesBkdSeq FROM SessionBkgs
  GROUP BY sesbkhRef, sesBkdSeq
  HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT sesNum) > 1
) a
JOIN SessionBkgs b ON a.sesbkhRef=b.sesbkhRef AND a.sesBkdSeq=b.sesBkdSeq
JOIN BKGDetail ON a.sesbkhRef=bkdRef AND a.sesBkdSeq=bkdSeq
JOIN BarCodes ON bkdBCDId=bcdId
JOIN PriceLookups ON bcdPLURecNo=pluRecNo
WHERE sesAddedOn > '1 JAN 2024'
ORDER BY a.sesbkhRef DESC, a.sesBkdSeq

title: Stock Variance Landscape report doesn't record all stock entries
text: Stock Variance Landscape report doesn't record all stock entries When running a Stock Variance Landscape report some items do not show as counted even though they clearly were. This means that items that had no variance might still show as having a variance on the report Checking stock movements and StockTakedet tables shows the item was definitely counted. See below for an example ticket reference in FreshDesk 68717. There are 2 parts to the Stock Take procedure, zeroise and stock count. The entry in the StockZeroise table looked like this. The entry in the StockMovements table looked like this The StockMovement was recorded approx 1/2 a minute after the zeroise stzDateFinalised time. The report only looked between the start and end time of the Zeroise. Hence the stock movements that occurred outside this time frame are disregarded by the report. To fix, update the stzDateFinalised time to after the time of the last StockMovement time for that stock take BEGIN TRANSACTION UPDATE StockZeroise SET stzDateFinalised='YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM' WHERE stzId=7 --COMMIT
description:
Stock Variance Landscape report doesn't record all stock entries


When running a Stock Variance Landscape report some items do not show as counted even though they clearly were.

This means that items that had no variance might still show as having a variance on the report

Checking stock movements and StockTakedet tables shows the item was definitely counted.


See below for an example ticket reference in FreshDesk 68717.


There are 2 parts to the Stock Take procedure, zeroise and stock count.

The entry in the StockZeroise table looked like this.

The entry in the StockMovements table looked like this

 

The StockMovement was recorded  approx 1/2 a minute after the zeroise stzDateFinalised time.

The report only looked between the start and end time of the Zeroise.

Hence the stock movements that occurred outside this time frame are disregarded by the report.


To fix, update the stzDateFinalised time to after the time of the last StockMovement time for that stock take


BEGIN TRANSACTION 

UPDATE StockZeroise

SET stzDateFinalised='YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM'

WHERE stzId=7

--COMMIT

title: SQL - Aggregate Data In One Row Into A Single Field
text: If you want to aggregate all data from one row into a single field, you can use STRING_AGG to do this. As an example of this in use in MStore terms, finding the total amount of people booked onto a session, and then all the bookings into one field. SELECT SUM(sesnum) [Total Booked For Session], STRING_AGG(sesbkhref, ', ') [Booking Refs.] FROM sessionbkgs where sesshdrecno=xxxx This will be the result that will be returned. SELECT bcdStkRecNo, bcdPLURecNo, STRING_AGG(CONVERT(NVARCHAR(max),bcdCode), ', ') FROM BarCodes JOIN Stock ON bcdStkRecNo=stkRecNo WHERE BarCodes.Deleted=0 AND Stock.Deleted=0 GROUP BY bcdStkRecNo, bcdPLURecNo When using this, and you get this error when Executing the SQL: STRING_AGG aggregation result exceeded the limit of 8000 bytes. Use LOB types to avoid result truncation. Convert the field's data type that you are aggregating CONVERT(NVARCHAR(MAX),[Field Name])
description:
If you want to aggregate all data from one row into a single field, you can use STRING_AGG to do this. As an example of this in use in MStore terms, finding the total amount of people booked onto a session, and then all the bookings into one field.


SELECT SUM(sesnum) [Total Booked For Session], STRING_AGG(sesbkhref, ', ') [Booking Refs.] FROM sessionbkgs
where sesshdrecno=xxxx


This will be the result that will be returned.



SELECT bcdStkRecNo, bcdPLURecNo, STRING_AGG(CONVERT(NVARCHAR(max),bcdCode), ', ')
FROM BarCodes
  JOIN Stock ON bcdStkRecNo=stkRecNo
WHERE BarCodes.Deleted=0 AND Stock.Deleted=0 
GROUP BY bcdStkRecNo, bcdPLURecNo



When using this, and you get this error when Executing the SQL:

STRING_AGG aggregation result exceeded the limit of 8000 bytes. Use LOB types to avoid result truncation.


Convert the field's data type that you are aggregating 

CONVERT(NVARCHAR(MAX),[Field Name])

title: Clearing Stuck Transactions
text: This guide explains how to: Safely remove duplicate or stuck transactions Manually add a missing opening (OPN) record for a till/cash drawer Step 1: Finding Stuck Transactions Before you begin, inspect the affected transaction or till session: SELECT * FROM TillTXNs If this returns a list of results then there is an issue, You’re looking for: Duplicate PAY lines (same ttnTillTXNNo, different ttnTillTXNSeq) Missing OPN (Opening) lines ttnStatus = 'Failed' or an ttnErrorMessage Or things along those lines. In theory, there should always been an error message. Step 2: Backing up a Table Depending on what you are doing, it may be best practice to backup the table before you continue. Use an identifiable field so you know which backup this is: SELECT * INTO bak_tilltxns_10APR25 FROM TillTXNs
description:
This guide explains how to:

  • Safely remove duplicate or stuck transactions
  • Manually add a missing opening (OPN) record for a till/cash drawer



Step 1: Finding Stuck Transactions

Before you begin, inspect the affected transaction or till session:

SELECT * FROM TillTXNs

If this returns a list of results then there is an issue,

You’re looking for:

  • Duplicate PAY lines (same ttnTillTXNNo, different ttnTillTXNSeq)
  • Missing OPN (Opening) lines
  • ttnStatus = 'Failed' or an ttnErrorMessage

Or things along those lines. In theory, there should always been an error message.



Step 2: Backing up a Table

Depending on what you are doing, it may be best practice to backup the table before you continue.

Use an identifiable field so you know which backup this is:

SELECT * INTO bak_tilltxns_10APR25
FROM TillTXNs

title: How to Update Forecasts & How Forecasting Works
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Summary How to Update Forecasts in Back Office Why Dashboard Figures May Be Missing How to Get Data from Previous Years When Forecasting Hasn't Been Done What Happens When You Click "Update Forecast" in BO? Some common problems when resolving Forecast tickets "Figures are missing or showing as zero" "The wrong year is being used to calculate projections" "Per Cap data isn’t appearing as expected" Understanding the Stored Procedures 1. MC_GetForecast [@Year] 2. MC_UpdateDepSummary [@YearsBack] 3. SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted [@Year] Summary The forecasting system in MStore allows for automatic population of future dashboard figures based on past performance. This ensures that sites have access to reliable Projected Footfall, Spend per Head, and Revenue Forecasts to compare against actual performance. However, you may occasionally encounter a dashboard that does not display figures from the previous year, or other issues alike. How to Update Forecasts in Back Office Open Dashboard Open Forecasts in the top left. Change the year in the top righ to the one before you want to update Click “Update Forecast”. Wait a few moments — this will process. Go back to the current year (or close the forecasts window) Your Dashboard should now be populated with projected and variance figures (below) If this does not happen, then read the rest of this article to find out why this may be. Why Dashboard Figures May Be Missing If you notice that no prior year comparison is available, it typically means one or more of the following: Forecasts for that previous year have not been generated, especially if the site hasn’t used forecasting for a while. Without this, the system has no historical data to base projections on. Days in the historical data are marked as “Closed” in the Staff Rota”, meaning they are excluded from future forecasts, even if data exists for them. The DepSummary table might be outdated or missing key figures like footfall or spend-per-head. How to Get Data from Previous Years When Forecasting Hasn't Been Done To fill in years where forecasting hasn't previously been done: Go to Forecasts. Select two years before the one you want forecasts for. For example, if you want to generate forecasts for 2024, select 2022 first, then repeat for 2023 Before updating the forecast, check the Staff Rota for that year: If any days are marked as “Closed”, they will be excluded from next year’s forecast. Change the Staff Rota for those days to “R.1” (or another open band) to ensure they are used. Click Save after editing the rota. Click “Update Forecast” to create or refresh the forecasts for that year. Do this for any years in between the one you started with and where you want to finish. Navigate to the year you want forecasts for to see what has pulled through. What Happens When You Click "Update Forecast" in BO? When a user clicks "Update Forecast" in the back office forecasts window: This triggers the following steps: MC_GetForecast [Year] runs first This creates new entries in the Forecasts table for the selected year. It uses "equivalent dates" from two years prior (based on weekday alignment) to estimate projected footfall. If DepSummary hasn't yet been updated, these forecast entries will lack data or contain zero projections. Then MC_UpdateDepSummary runs This refreshes the DepSummary table with transaction-based footfall and revenue data. It also calculates Projected Spend per Head using SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted internally. Some common problems when resolving Forecast tickets "Figures are missing or showing as zero" Possible reasons: The Staff Rota for the base year has dates marked as Closed. The DepSummary is missing spend or footfall figures for those dates. "The wrong year is being used to calculate projections" Explanation: Forecasts use the date from two years prior, not the immediate previous year. What to clarify: For example, a forecast for 2024 uses data from 2022. If 2022 was never forcasted or was incomplete, 2024 projections may be inaccurate or empty. "Per Cap data isn’t appearing as expected" Most likely cause: The system will only populate Per Cap values where the existing value is NULL. Why: This is by design — to allow customers to manually enter their own Per Cap values without them being overwritten. Lesser likely cause: The DepSummary hasn't updated to the years ahead as required. Look for: The DepSummary table should be 2 years ahead if you have updated the Forecast. If it isn't, then you may have to extend the DepSummary table manually. Understanding the Stored Procedures 1. MC_GetForecast [@Year] This is the first procedure to run when updating a forecast. What it does: Creates a new row in the Forecasts table for every date in the specified year. Each row includes: A projected footfall value for the day. A staffing band (e.g., R.1, R.2) based on the expected footfall. A reference to an “equivalent date” from one year prior, matched by weekday to align behaviour. If the footfall on the equivalent date is 0: The system sets the staff band to "Closed" (unless a manual Per Cap override exists, in which case it sets R.1). 2. MC_UpdateDepSummary [@YearsBack] This procedure runs immediately after the forecast rows are created. What it does: Populates the DepSummary table with: Actual footfall (from Footfall logs or tills) Actual revenue (from CashDraw and Payment tables) It works across multiple transaction types and calculates accurate totals per department. The update only affects rows where dsuImported is NULL or not equal to 1, so manually imported data is preserved. At the end of the process, it calls SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted for each year up to two years ahead, so that Projected Spend per Head is calculated for future dates. 3. SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted [@Year] This final stored procedure focuses specifically on calculating Spend per Head. What it does: For each date, it calculates: Spend per head = revenue ÷ footfall Using DepSummary figures from the previous year. These values are then copied into future-year entries to populate the dsuProjectedPerCap column. Important rule: It only fills in dsuProjectedPerCap where the value is NULL. This prevents overwriting manually-entered data and ensures that users can override figures without them being recalculated on the next forecast update.
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Summary
  • How to Update Forecasts in Back Office
  • Why Dashboard Figures May Be Missing
  • How to Get Data from Previous Years When Forecasting Hasn't Been Done
  • What Happens When You Click "Update Forecast" in BO?
  • Some common problems when resolving Forecast tickets
    • "Figures are missing or showing as zero"
    •  "The wrong year is being used to calculate projections"
    • "Per Cap data isn’t appearing as expected"
  • Understanding the Stored Procedures
    • 1. MC_GetForecast [@Year]
    • 2. MC_UpdateDepSummary [@YearsBack]
    • 3. SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted [@Year]

Summary

The forecasting system in MStore allows for automatic population of future dashboard figures based on past performance. This ensures that sites have access to reliable Projected Footfall, Spend per Head, and Revenue Forecasts to compare against actual performance.


However, you may occasionally encounter a dashboard that does not display figures from the previous year, or other issues alike.


How to Update Forecasts in Back Office

  1. Open Dashboard

  2. Open Forecasts in the top left.

  3. Change the year in the top righ to the one before you want to update

  4. Click “Update Forecast”.

  5. Wait a few moments — this will process.

  6. Go back to the current year (or close the forecasts window)


Your Dashboard should now be populated with projected and variance figures (below)



If this does not happen, then read the rest of this article to find out why this may be.


Why Dashboard Figures May Be Missing

If you notice that no prior year comparison is available, it typically means one or more of the following:

  • Forecasts for that previous year have not been generated, especially if the site hasn’t used forecasting for a while. Without this, the system has no historical data to base projections on.
  • Days in the historical data are marked as “Closed” in the Staff Rota”, meaning they are excluded from future forecasts, even if data exists for them.
  • The DepSummary table might be outdated or missing key figures like footfall or spend-per-head.


How to Get Data from Previous Years When Forecasting Hasn't Been Done

To fill in years where forecasting hasn't previously been done:

  1. Go to Forecasts.

  2. Select two years before the one you want forecasts for.

    For example, if you want to generate forecasts for 2024, select 2022 first, then repeat for 2023

  3. Before updating the forecast, check the Staff Rota for that year:

    • If any days are marked as “Closed”, they will be excluded from next year’s forecast.

    • Change the Staff Rota for those days to “R.1” (or another open band) to ensure they are used.

  4. Click Save after editing the rota.

  5. Click “Update Forecast” to create or refresh the forecasts for that year. Do this for any years in between the one you started with and where you want to finish.

  6. Navigate to the year you want forecasts for to see what has pulled through.


What Happens When You Click "Update Forecast" in BO?

When a user clicks "Update Forecast" in the back office forecasts window:

This triggers the following steps:

  1. MC_GetForecast [Year] runs first
    • This creates new entries in the Forecasts table for the selected year.
    • It uses "equivalent dates" from two years prior (based on weekday alignment) to estimate projected footfall.
    • If DepSummary hasn't yet been updated, these forecast entries will lack data or contain zero projections.
  2. Then MC_UpdateDepSummary runs
    • This refreshes the DepSummary table with transaction-based footfall and revenue data.
    • It also calculates Projected Spend per Head using SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted internally.


Some common problems when resolving Forecast tickets

  • "Figures are missing or showing as zero"

    • Possible reasons:

      • The Staff Rota for the base year has dates marked as Closed.

      • The DepSummary is missing spend or footfall figures for those dates.

  •  "The wrong year is being used to calculate projections"

    • Explanation: Forecasts use the date from two years prior, not the immediate previous year.

    • What to clarify:

      • For example, a forecast for 2024 uses data from 2022.

      • If 2022 was never forcasted or was incomplete, 2024 projections may be inaccurate or empty.

  • "Per Cap data isn’t appearing as expected"

    • Most likely cause: The system will only populate Per Cap values where the existing value is NULL.

    • Why: This is by design — to allow customers to manually enter their own Per Cap values without them being overwritten.

    • Lesser likely cause: The DepSummary hasn't updated to the years ahead as required.

    • Look for: The DepSummary table should be 2 years ahead if you have updated the Forecast. If it isn't, then you may have to extend the DepSummary table manually.



Understanding the Stored Procedures


1. MC_GetForecast [@Year]

This is the first procedure to run when updating a forecast.

What it does:

  • Creates a new row in the Forecasts table for every date in the specified year.

  • Each row includes:

    • A projected footfall value for the day.

    • A staffing band (e.g., R.1, R.2) based on the expected footfall.

    • A reference to an “equivalent date” from one year prior, matched by weekday to align behaviour.

  • If the footfall on the equivalent date is 0:

    • The system sets the staff band to "Closed" (unless a manual Per Cap override exists, in which case it sets R.1).



2. MC_UpdateDepSummary [@YearsBack]

This procedure runs immediately after the forecast rows are created.

What it does:

  • Populates the DepSummary table with:

    • Actual footfall (from Footfall logs or tills)

    • Actual revenue (from CashDraw and Payment tables)

  • It works across multiple transaction types and calculates accurate totals per department.

  • The update only affects rows where dsuImported is NULL or not equal to 1, so manually imported data is preserved.

  • At the end of the process, it calls SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted for each year up to two years ahead, so that Projected Spend per Head is calculated for future dates.



3. SUPP_PopulateProjectedPerCap_DayAdjusted [@Year]

This final stored procedure focuses specifically on calculating Spend per Head.

What it does:

  • For each date, it calculates:

    • Spend per head = revenue ÷ footfall

    • Using DepSummary figures from the previous year.

  • These values are then copied into future-year entries to populate the dsuProjectedPerCap column.

  • Important rule: It only fills in dsuProjectedPerCap where the value is NULL. This prevents overwriting manually-entered data and ensures that users can override figures without them being recalculated on the next forecast update.

title: How to Set Up Automatic Database Backups
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction Prerequisites 1. Check SQL Server Agent is Installed and Running To enable SQL Server Agent: Prepare the Backup Folder Set Up the SQL Server Agent Job 1. Open SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) 2. Create a New Job Add Steps for Each Database Step A: Backup Script Click the Steps tab, then New. Step B: Cleanup Script Enable xp_cmdshell Schedule the Job You're Done! Notes Introduction This guide explains how to schedule automatic daily backups of one or more SQL Server databases using SQL Server Agent. The setup includes: Verifying that SQL Server Agent is installed and running Automatically generating uniquely named backup files based on the date Automatically cleaning up backups older than 2 days Easily backing up multiple databases in a single job, with no need to edit the scripts This guide assumes prior knowledge of SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS), SQL Server Agent, and working with T-SQL scripts. It does not cover basic concepts such as connecting to a SQL Server instance, navigating SSMS, or managing user permissions. Prerequisites 1. Check SQL Server Agent is Installed and Running SQL Server Agent is required to schedule and automate tasks in SQL Server. It is not available in SQL Server Express. To enable SQL Server Agent: Open SQL Server Configuration Manager. Expand SQL Server Services. Look for SQL Server Agent (e.g. SQL Server Agent (MSSQLSERVER) or named instance). If it’s not present, you will need to install it via SQL Server setup. If it’s installed but stopped, right-click it and choose Start. Prepare the Backup Folder Before continuing, make sure the following folder exists: C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS If it doesn't exist, create it manually. This folder will be used to store all automated backup files. Set Up the SQL Server Agent Job 1. Open SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) Connect to your server and expand the SQL Server Agent node. 2. Create a New Job Right-click Jobs → New Job Name the job: Daily Backup (or any descriptive name) Add Steps for Each Database If you want to auto backup more than one database on the same server; for each database you want to back up, you will add two steps: A Backup step (uses the selected database context) A Cleanup step (uses the same database context) You can repeat this pair of steps for as many databases as you need. Just make sure you set the database it runs against. Step A: Backup Script Click the Steps tab, then New. Name the step: 'Auto Backup - [DatabaseName]' Type: Transact-SQL script (T-SQL) Database: Select the database to back up (e.g. MStore, MStoreUAT, etc.) Paste the following script: DECLARE @BasePath NVARCHAR(255) = 'C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS'; DECLARE @DateString NVARCHAR(20) = CONVERT(CHAR(8), GETDATE(), 112); DECLARE @DatabaseName NVARCHAR(128) = DB_NAME(); DECLARE @Counter INT = 0; DECLARE @FileName NVARCHAR(260); DECLARE @FileExists INT; WHILE 1 = 1 BEGIN SET @FileName = @BasePath + @DatabaseName + '_' + @DateString + CASE WHEN @Counter = 0 THEN '' ELSE '_' + CAST(@Counter AS NVARCHAR) END + '.bak'; EXEC master.dbo.xp_fileexist @FileName, @FileExists OUTPUT; IF @FileExists = 0 BREAK; SET @Counter += 1; END BACKUP DATABASE @DatabaseName TO DISK = @FileName WITH INIT, COMPRESSION; Step B: Cleanup Script Click New again to add the cleanup step. Name the step: Cleanup - [DatabaseName] Type: Transact-SQL script (T-SQL) Database: Use the same database selected in the previous step. Paste the following script: DECLARE @BasePath NVARCHAR(255) = 'C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS\'; DECLARE @DatabaseName NVARCHAR(128) = DB_NAME(); DECLARE @CleanupCommand NVARCHAR(4000); SET @CleanupCommand = 'forfiles /p "' + @BasePath + '" /m ' + @DatabaseName + '_*.bak /d -2 /c "cmd /c del @path"'; EXEC master.dbo.xp_cmdshell @CleanupCommand; Note: This specific script will delete all .bak files for the selected database that are older than 2 days. Edit as needed. Enable xp_cmdshell If xp_cmdshell is not already enabled on your server, run this in a new query window once: EXEC sp_configure 'show advanced options', 1; RECONFIGURE; EXEC sp_configure 'xp_cmdshell', 1; RECONFIGURE; You do not need to include this in the scheduled job. Schedule the Job Go to the Schedules tab. Click New. Name the schedule: Something like 'Daily MStore Backup Schedule' Set Frequency to: Daily Set Time to: required time for that site (04:00) Click OK You're Done! Your SQL Server Agent job is now set up to: Automatically create backups of each selected database every night/morning Use uniquely named files that include the date and a counter (e.g. MStore_20250412_1.bak) Automatically delete any backups older than 2 days Require no editing of the script to add additional databases — simply copy the steps and change the database context in the dropdown Notes You can still take manual backups as needed — this setup will not interfere with those. Make sure the SQL Server Agent service account has permission to write and delete in C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS. If you're using SQL Server Express, you’ll need to use Task Scheduler with PowerShell instead, as SQL Server Agent is not available. Remember this doesn't empty the recycle bin! You may want to set up an auto delete task for the recycle bin at a repeating time based on the size of the backups.
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Introduction
  • Prerequisites
    • 1. Check SQL Server Agent is Installed and Running
      • To enable SQL Server Agent:
  • Prepare the Backup Folder
  • Set Up the SQL Server Agent Job
    • 1. Open SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)
    • 2. Create a New Job
  • Add Steps for Each Database
    • Step A: Backup Script
    • Click the Steps tab, then New.
    • Step B: Cleanup Script
    • Enable xp_cmdshell
  • Schedule the Job
  • You're Done!
  • Notes

Introduction

This guide explains how to schedule automatic daily backups of one or more SQL Server databases using SQL Server Agent. The setup includes:

  • Verifying that SQL Server Agent is installed and running

  • Automatically generating uniquely named backup files based on the date

  • Automatically cleaning up backups older than 2 days

  • Easily backing up multiple databases in a single job, with no need to edit the scripts



This guide assumes prior knowledge of SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS), SQL Server Agent, and working with T-SQL scripts. It does not cover basic concepts such as connecting to a SQL Server instance, navigating SSMS, or managing user permissions. 


Prerequisites

1. Check SQL Server Agent is Installed and Running

SQL Server Agent is required to schedule and automate tasks in SQL Server. It is not available in SQL Server Express.

To enable SQL Server Agent:

  1. Open SQL Server Configuration Manager.

  2. Expand SQL Server Services.

  3. Look for SQL Server Agent (e.g. SQL Server Agent (MSSQLSERVER) or named instance).

  4. If it’s not present, you will need to install it via SQL Server setup.

  5. If it’s installed but stopped, right-click it and choose Start.

Prepare the Backup Folder

Before continuing, make sure the following folder exists:

C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS

If it doesn't exist, create it manually. This folder will be used to store all automated backup files.

Set Up the SQL Server Agent Job

1. Open SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)

Connect to your server and expand the SQL Server Agent node.

2. Create a New Job

  • Right-click Jobs → New Job

  • Name the job: Daily Backup (or any descriptive name)

Add Steps for Each Database

If you want to auto backup more than one database on the same server; for each database you want to back up, you will add two steps:

  • A Backup step (uses the selected database context)

  • A Cleanup step (uses the same database context)

You can repeat this pair of steps for as many databases as you need. Just make sure you set the database it runs against.

Step A: Backup Script

  1. Click the Steps tab, then New.

  2. Name the step: 'Auto Backup - [DatabaseName]'

  3. Type: Transact-SQL script (T-SQL)

  4. Database: Select the database to back up (e.g. MStore, MStoreUAT, etc.)

  5. Paste the following script:

DECLARE @BasePath NVARCHAR(255) = 'C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS';
DECLARE @DateString NVARCHAR(20) = CONVERT(CHAR(8), GETDATE(), 112);
DECLARE @DatabaseName NVARCHAR(128) = DB_NAME();
DECLARE @Counter INT = 0;
DECLARE @FileName NVARCHAR(260);
DECLARE @FileExists INT;
WHILE 1 = 1
BEGIN SET @FileName = @BasePath + @DatabaseName + '_' + @DateString + CASE WHEN @Counter = 0 THEN '' ELSE '_' + CAST(@Counter AS NVARCHAR) END + '.bak'; EXEC master.dbo.xp_fileexist @FileName, @FileExists OUTPUT; IF @FileExists = 0 BREAK; SET @Counter += 1;
END
BACKUP DATABASE @DatabaseName
TO DISK = @FileName
WITH INIT, COMPRESSION;

Step B: Cleanup Script

  1. Click New again to add the cleanup step.

  2. Name the step: Cleanup - [DatabaseName]

  3. Type: Transact-SQL script (T-SQL)

  4. Database: Use the same database selected in the previous step.

  5. Paste the following script:


DECLARE @BasePath NVARCHAR(255) = 'C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS\';
DECLARE @DatabaseName NVARCHAR(128) = DB_NAME();
DECLARE @CleanupCommand NVARCHAR(4000);

SET @CleanupCommand = 'forfiles /p "' + @BasePath + '" /m ' + @DatabaseName + '_*.bak /d -2 /c "cmd /c del @path"';

EXEC master.dbo.xp_cmdshell @CleanupCommand;


Note: This specific script will delete all .bak files for the selected database that are older than 2 days. Edit as needed.

Enable xp_cmdshell

If xp_cmdshell is not already enabled on your server, run this in a new query window once:


EXEC sp_configure 'show advanced options', 1;
RECONFIGURE;
EXEC sp_configure 'xp_cmdshell', 1;
RECONFIGURE;


You do not need to include this in the scheduled job.

Schedule the Job

  1. Go to the Schedules tab.
  2. Click New.
  3. Name the schedule: Something like 'Daily MStore Backup Schedule'
  4. Set Frequency to: Daily
  5. Set Time to: required time for that site (04:00)
  6. Click OK

You're Done!

Your SQL Server Agent job is now set up to:

  • Automatically create backups of each selected database every night/morning

  • Use uniquely named files that include the date and a counter (e.g. MStore_20250412_1.bak)

  • Automatically delete any backups older than 2 days

  • Require no editing of the script to add additional databases — simply copy the steps and change the database context in the dropdown

Notes

  • You can still take manual backups as needed — this setup will not interfere with those.

  • Make sure the SQL Server Agent service account has permission to write and delete in C:\ProgramData\Merac\BACKUPS.

  • If you're using SQL Server Express, you’ll need to use Task Scheduler with PowerShell instead, as SQL Server Agent is not available.

  • Remember this doesn't empty the recycle bin! You may want to set up an auto delete task for the recycle bin at a repeating time based on the size of the backups.

title: Updating Order Option Transaction Detail Lines Tax Codes
text: If a customer has reported that order option lines in transaction reports were showing with the wrong tax code of the main item the order option item was sold with, you need to update the PDBUpdater from 3.19.15, and then update the old transaction lines with the below SQL. DECLARE @SQL NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKTXNDetail'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM TXNDetail' EXEC (@SQL) BEGIN TRANSACTION UPDATE a SET txnTaxCode1=priTaxCode1 FROM TXNDetail a JOIN TXNHeader ON txhBranch=txnBranch AND txhNo=txnNo JOIN BarCodes ON txnBCDId=bcdId JOIN Prices ON bcdPLURecNo=priPLURecNo AND txhCompleted BETWEEN priValidFrom AND priValidTo AND txnTaxCode1 <> priTaxCode1 WHERE txhBranch=1 AND txnLinkedTxnSeq IS NOT NULL AND txhCompleted > '1 JAN 2020' --COMMIT You will also need to update the txnTaxAmount1 field, which can be used below. However, make sure that none of the tax rates had been changed between the transaction was made and now, as the tax amount would be updated to today's tax rate. DECLARE @SQL NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKTXNDetail'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM TXNDetail' EXEC (@SQL) BEGIN TRANSACTION UPDATE a SET a.txnTaxAmount1 = dbo.FC_GetLineTaxAmount(a.txnTaxType1, a.txnTaxCode1, a.txnItemSellPrice, a.txnQty) FROM TXNDetail a JOIN BAKTXNDetail19May25 b ON a.txnNo = b.txnNo AND a.txnSeq = b.txnSeq JOIN TXNHeader ON txhBranch=b.txnBranch AND txhNo=b.txnNo JOIN BarCodes ON b.txnBCDId=bcdId JOIN Prices ON bcdPLURecNo=priPLURecNo AND txhCompleted BETWEEN priValidFrom AND priValidTo AND b.txnTaxCode1 <> priTaxCode1 WHERE txhBranch=1 AND b.txnLinkedTxnSeq IS NOT NULL AND txhCompleted > '1 JAN 2020' AND a.txnTaxCode1 <> 'R' --COMMIT
description:
If a customer has reported that order option lines in transaction reports were showing with the wrong tax code of the main item the order option item was sold with, you need to update the PDBUpdater from 3.19.15, and then update the old transaction lines with the below SQL.


DECLARE @SQL NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKTXNDetail'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM TXNDetail'
EXEC (@SQL)

BEGIN TRANSACTION 
UPDATE a
SET txnTaxCode1=priTaxCode1
FROM TXNDetail a
JOIN TXNHeader ON txhBranch=txnBranch AND txhNo=txnNo 
JOIN BarCodes ON txnBCDId=bcdId
JOIN Prices ON bcdPLURecNo=priPLURecNo AND txhCompleted BETWEEN priValidFrom AND priValidTo AND txnTaxCode1 <> priTaxCode1
WHERE txhBranch=1 AND txnLinkedTxnSeq IS NOT NULL
AND txhCompleted > '1 JAN 2020'
--COMMIT


You will also need to update the txnTaxAmount1 field, which can be used below. However, make sure that none of the tax rates had been changed between the transaction was made and now, as the tax amount would be updated to today's tax rate.


DECLARE @SQL NVARCHAR(100) = 'SELECT * INTO BAKTXNDetail'+ REPLACE(CONVERT(NVARCHAR, GETDATE(), 6),' ','') +' FROM TXNDetail'
EXEC (@SQL)

BEGIN TRANSACTION 
UPDATE a
SET a.txnTaxAmount1 = dbo.FC_GetLineTaxAmount(a.txnTaxType1, a.txnTaxCode1, a.txnItemSellPrice, a.txnQty)
FROM TXNDetail a
JOIN BAKTXNDetail19May25 b ON a.txnNo = b.txnNo AND a.txnSeq = b.txnSeq
JOIN TXNHeader ON txhBranch=b.txnBranch AND txhNo=b.txnNo 
JOIN BarCodes ON b.txnBCDId=bcdId
JOIN Prices ON bcdPLURecNo=priPLURecNo AND txhCompleted BETWEEN priValidFrom AND priValidTo AND b.txnTaxCode1 <> priTaxCode1
WHERE txhBranch=1 AND b.txnLinkedTxnSeq IS NOT NULL
AND txhCompleted > '1 JAN 2020' AND a.txnTaxCode1 <> 'R'
--COMMIT

title: Extend the DepSummary Table Manually
text: The DepSummary table contains daily department-level summary data used in Forecasts. This guide explains how to extend it up to 31st December of a future year, ensuring that projections and reporting can continue without interruption. You may need to use this if the DepSummary table hasn't automatically extended its dates. This should happen when the Forecast is updated, but doesn't always. This can affect PerCap data. Steps: Open SSMS and connect to the relevant MStore database. Review the Script Below and update the @TargetYear to the year you want to extend to: -- =================================================================================== -- Extend DepSummary Table in MStore -- Author: Leo Brown -- Description: -- This script extends the depsummary table to 31st December of a specified year. -- It works by copying the most recent 30 days of data and incrementing the dates, -- repeating the process until the target year is fully populated. -- Useful for preparing future projections and avoiding reporting gaps. -- =================================================================================== DECLARE @TargetYear INT = 2027; -- Change this to the desired year DECLARE @LastDateInTable DATE = (SELECT MAX(dsuDate) FROM depsummary); DECLARE @EndDate DATE = DATEFROMPARTS(@TargetYear, 12, 31); DECLARE @DaysToCopy INT; DECLARE @CopyStartDate DATE; WHILE @LastDateInTable = 30 THEN 30 ELSE DATEDIFF(DAY, @LastDateInTable, @EndDate) END; SET @CopyStartDate = DATEADD(DAY, -@DaysToCopy + 1, @LastDateInTable); INSERT INTO depsummary ( dsuBranch, dsuDate, dsuDpt, dsuSubDpt, dsuFootfall, dsuAmount, dsuProjectedPerCap, dsuImported ) SELECT dsuBranch, DATEADD(DAY, @DaysToCopy, dsuDate) AS dsuDate, dsuDpt, dsuSubDpt, dsuFootfall, dsuAmount, dsuProjectedPerCap, dsuImported FROM depsummary WHERE dsuDate BETWEEN @CopyStartDate AND @LastDateInTable; -- Update last date after insertion SET @LastDateInTable = (SELECT MAX(dsuDate) FROM depsummary); END;
description:
The DepSummary table contains daily department-level summary data used in Forecasts. This guide explains how to extend it up to 31st December of a future year, ensuring that projections and reporting can continue without interruption.


You may need to use this if the DepSummary table hasn't automatically extended its dates. This should happen when the Forecast is updated, but doesn't always. This can affect PerCap data.


Steps:

  1. Open SSMS and connect to the relevant MStore database.

  2. Review the Script Below and update the @TargetYear to the year you want to extend to:


-- ===================================================================================
-- Extend DepSummary Table in MStore
-- Author: Leo Brown
-- Description: 
--     This script extends the depsummary table to 31st December of a specified year.
--     It works by copying the most recent 30 days of data and incrementing the dates,
--     repeating the process until the target year is fully populated.
--     Useful for preparing future projections and avoiding reporting gaps.
-- ===================================================================================

DECLARE @TargetYear INT = 2027; -- Change this to the desired year


DECLARE @LastDateInTable DATE = (SELECT MAX(dsuDate) FROM depsummary);
DECLARE @EndDate DATE = DATEFROMPARTS(@TargetYear, 12, 31);
DECLARE @DaysToCopy INT;
DECLARE @CopyStartDate DATE;

WHILE @LastDateInTable < @EndDate
BEGIN
    -- Calculate how many days can copy in this batch (max 30)
    SET @DaysToCopy = CASE 
                        WHEN DATEDIFF(DAY, @LastDateInTable, @EndDate) >= 30 THEN 30 
                        ELSE DATEDIFF(DAY, @LastDateInTable, @EndDate) 
                      END;

    SET @CopyStartDate = DATEADD(DAY, -@DaysToCopy + 1, @LastDateInTable);

    INSERT INTO depsummary (
        dsuBranch,
        dsuDate,
        dsuDpt,
        dsuSubDpt,
        dsuFootfall,
        dsuAmount,
        dsuProjectedPerCap,
        dsuImported
    )
    SELECT
        dsuBranch,
        DATEADD(DAY, @DaysToCopy, dsuDate) AS dsuDate,
        dsuDpt,
        dsuSubDpt,
        dsuFootfall,
        dsuAmount,
        dsuProjectedPerCap,
        dsuImported
    FROM depsummary
    WHERE dsuDate BETWEEN @CopyStartDate AND @LastDateInTable;

    -- Update last date after insertion
    SET @LastDateInTable = (SELECT MAX(dsuDate) FROM depsummary);
END;

title: Collation conflict between "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS" and "Latin1_General_CI_AS"
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Identify the fail points Fix the issue Auto Create Fix Script Applies to: MStore upgrades – typically during execution of SQL upgrade scripts. During an MStore upgrade, you may encounter an error like the following when running a script: "Implicit conversion of varchar value to varchar cannot be performed because the collation of the value is unresolved due to a collation conflict between "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS" and "Latin1_General_CI_AS" in add operator." This error is typically triggered by a mismatch in collation between two varchar or nvarchar values being concatenated (e.g. using +) or compared (e.g. using = or JOIN). It's rare, but it can cause an upgrade to fail if not handled properly. Identify the fail points When an MStore upgrade script fails with a collation conflict error, the first step is to identify which columns are using the wrong collation. You can do this by running the following query in the target database: SELECT TABLE_NAME, COLUMN_NAME, DATA_TYPE, COLLATION_NAME FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS WHERE COLLATION_NAME IS NOT NULL AND DATA_TYPE IN ('varchar', 'char', 'text', 'nvarchar', 'nchar', 'ntext') ORDER BY COLLATION_NAME; This will list all string-based columns with an explicit collation setting. You're specifically looking for columns that use: Latin1_General_CI_AS These are incorrect for MStore and are typically the cause of issues. They should appear at the top of the results. The correct one should be lower down and look like this: SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS This is the default, so any mismatch (especially Latin1_General_CI_AS) should be flagged for correction or handled in the upgrade script. Fix the issue Once you’ve identified the columns using the wrong collation (e.g. Latin1_General_CI_AS), you need to create a script to explicitly update each one to the correct collation. (see next section) Example -- TABLE: pbaTEST ALTER TABLE pbaTEST ALTER COLUMN pbaBarcode VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbaTEST ALTER COLUMN pbaKeyString VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; -- TABLE: pbTEST ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbCaption VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbFontName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbPicNormal VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbPicPressed VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbIcon VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS; You must specify the full data type when altering the collation — including the length (e.g. VARCHAR(255)), otherwise the command will fail. Auto Create Fix Script Because I’m really nice, I’ve included a handy script below that will automatically generate all the ALTER TABLE lines you need to fix collation issues. It scans the current database for any varchar, nvarchar, or other text-based columns using the wrong collation (Latin1_General_CI_AS), and builds a full list of ALTER TABLE ... ALTER COLUMN ... COLLATE commands to bring them in line with the expected collation (SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS). Put your SQL in Results to Text (Ctrl-T) and run this: DECLARE @CorrectCollation SYSNAME = 'SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS'; SELECT 'ALTER TABLE ' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME) + ' ALTER COLUMN ' + QUOTENAME(COLUMN_NAME) + ' ' + DATA_TYPE + CASE WHEN CHARACTER_MAXIMUM_LENGTH = -1 THEN '(MAX)' ELSE '(' + CAST(CHARACTER_MAXIMUM_LENGTH AS VARCHAR(10)) + ')' END + ' COLLATE ' + @CorrectCollation + ';' AS [FixScript] FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS WHERE COLLATION_NAME IS NOT NULL AND DATA_TYPE IN ('varchar', 'char', 'text', 'nvarchar', 'nchar', 'ntext') AND COLLATION_NAME <> @CorrectCollation ORDER BY TABLE_NAME, COLUMN_NAME; This will produce the change script for you. If I have written all of this correctly, your upgrade should now work without getting this error.
description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Identify the fail points
  • Fix the issue
  • Auto Create Fix Script


Applies to: MStore upgrades  – typically during execution of SQL upgrade scripts.


During an MStore upgrade, you may encounter an error like the following when running a script:

"Implicit conversion of varchar value to varchar cannot be performed because the collation of the value is unresolved due to a collation conflict between "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS" and "Latin1_General_CI_AS" in add operator."

This error is typically triggered by a mismatch in collation between two varchar or nvarchar values being concatenated (e.g. using +) or compared (e.g. using = or JOIN). It's rare, but it can cause an upgrade to fail if not handled properly.



Identify the fail points

When an MStore upgrade script fails with a collation conflict error, the first step is to identify which columns are using the wrong collation.


You can do this by running the following query in the target database:

SELECT TABLE_NAME, COLUMN_NAME, DATA_TYPE, COLLATION_NAME
FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS
WHERE COLLATION_NAME IS NOT NULL
  AND DATA_TYPE IN ('varchar', 'char', 'text', 'nvarchar', 'nchar', 'ntext')
ORDER BY COLLATION_NAME;

This will list all string-based columns with an explicit collation setting. You're specifically looking for columns that use:

Latin1_General_CI_AS

These are incorrect for MStore and are typically the cause of issues. They should appear at the top of the results.

The correct one should be lower down and look like this:

SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS

This is the default, so any mismatch (especially Latin1_General_CI_AS) should be flagged for correction or handled in the upgrade script.


Fix the issue

Once you’ve identified the columns using the wrong collation (e.g. Latin1_General_CI_AS), you need to create a script to explicitly update each one to the correct collation. (see next section)


Example

-- TABLE: pbaTEST
ALTER TABLE pbaTEST ALTER COLUMN pbaBarcode VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbaTEST ALTER COLUMN pbaKeyString VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;

-- TABLE: pbTEST
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbCaption VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbFontName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbPicNormal VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbPicPressed VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
ALTER TABLE pbTEST ALTER COLUMN pnbIcon VARCHAR(255) COLLATE SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS;
You must specify the full data type when altering the collation — including the length (e.g. VARCHAR(255)), otherwise the command will fail.


Auto Create Fix Script

Because I’m really nice, I’ve included a handy script below that will automatically generate all the ALTER TABLE lines you need to fix collation issues.


It scans the current database for any varchar, nvarchar, or other text-based columns using the wrong collation (Latin1_General_CI_AS), and builds a full list of ALTER TABLE ... ALTER COLUMN ... COLLATE commands to bring them in line with the expected collation (SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS).


Put your SQL in Results to Text (Ctrl-T) and run this:


DECLARE @CorrectCollation SYSNAME = 'SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS';

SELECT 
    'ALTER TABLE ' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME) + 
    ' ALTER COLUMN ' + QUOTENAME(COLUMN_NAME) + ' ' +
    DATA_TYPE + 
    CASE 
        WHEN CHARACTER_MAXIMUM_LENGTH = -1 THEN '(MAX)' 
        ELSE '(' + CAST(CHARACTER_MAXIMUM_LENGTH AS VARCHAR(10)) + ')' 
    END +
    ' COLLATE ' + @CorrectCollation + ';' AS [FixScript]
FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS
WHERE 
    COLLATION_NAME IS NOT NULL
    AND DATA_TYPE IN ('varchar', 'char', 'text', 'nvarchar', 'nchar', 'ntext')
    AND COLLATION_NAME <> @CorrectCollation
ORDER BY TABLE_NAME, COLUMN_NAME;

This will produce the change script for you. 


If I have written all of this correctly, your upgrade should now work without getting this error.
